Leney.

To Sask., April 1905.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

No individual who is asked to answer a general questionnaire on pioneer life becomes responsible for you to answer it. It is not necessary to answer every question on this form. If there is not sufficient space to write the answers, use extra sheets of paper. If there is not sufficient space to write the answers, use extra sheets of paper.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Dear Questionnaire,

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diet: What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" will still be being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please pass a copy along here (and one will be sent to you).

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

All questionnaires:

- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life; sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent collection.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Mackay Hall,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Gamble, D. Gordon
Lamey.

To Sask., April 19, 1925.

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A VIEW OF EXPLAINING TO THE PERSON

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it will be able to answer all questions. Some of the questions here will not apply to everyone; others may be impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about answering them. Others may prove too difficult to answer, but if there is not sufficient space to write answers, please use the back of the sheet or describe the particular events in a separate paragraph.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914 and may be answered by anyone who has personal experiences of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Diary: What Did Saskatchewan Pioneers Do?", is still being circulated. If you have not already answered it, you will find it worthwhile to do so.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer health conditions
- Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
- Pioneer housing conditions
- Pioneer education and churchwork
- Pioneer farming experiences

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent archives of the province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Board,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
Gamble, D. Gordon
Laney.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you'd rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: D. GRANDMABLE.
2. Your address: L.E.M.E.Y.
3. Date: MARCH 31, 1902.
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Arthur, Ontario.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? JAMES F. GRAMBLE, Merchant Tailor.
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): To Saskatchewan, April 19th, 1900.
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.).
9. What were your reasons for coming West? I had a notion of taking a job as a railway bookkeeper and my mother agreed to come west to help the family. My father had the notion for some time before.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information)? All from the above.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

My mother's folks did not think much of it. My mother was unwilling to travel there and thought it would be a long way off.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

With a brother.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Sitter's effect on C.P.R.

14. What incidents of the journey best do you remember? (People you met on the trip, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other experiences, etc.)

Nothing exciting. Came from Bannock Station.

To Saskatoon in 7 days.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

Just right in front of town. Stayed about two weeks.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Out of Saskatoon in Old Butteful Trail.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?
